docs.text: Welcome to the CSS Gradients Guide! Unlock the power of stunning visuals with CSS Gradients. What is this? The CSS Gradients Guide is your friendly companion for mastering the art of creating beautiful, code-based gradients. Designed for beginners and designers alike, this application (and guide) helps you transition from flat colors to mesmerizing, multi-dimensional backgrounds without needing complex graphics software. Who is this for? Web Beginners: Learn the basics of CSS background properties. Designers: Prototype gradients quickly in the browser. Developers: Copy-paste ready-to-use gradient code into your projects. What You Will Learn In this documentation, you will: 1. Set up your environment to experiment with gradients. 2. Create your first Linear, Radial, and Conic gradients. 3. Understand the key differences between gradient types. 4. Troubleshoot common issues. Let's blend in!

docs.text: Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) Here are answers to common questions about using CSS Gradients. Q: Why is my gradient not showing up? A: Check your syntax. Ensure you are using the background or background-image property. Also, make sure your HTML element has a defined height and width ; otherwise, it might be invisible! Q: Can I use color names instead of Hex codes? A: Yes! You can use standard names like red , blue , papayawhip , or mintcream . However, Hex codes (like #ff5733 ) allow for precise color matching. Q: How do I make a gradient transparent? A: Use RGBA values. The last number in rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5) controls opacity (0 is transparent, 1 is solid). Example: linear-gradient(to bottom, red, rgba(255, 0, 0, 0)) fades from red to invisible. Q: Do these gradients work on mobile phones? A: Yes, modern CSS gradients are supported by all major mobile browsers (Chrome, Safari, Firefox on Android/iOS). Q: Can I animate a gradient? A: Yes! By animating the background-position property and making the background-size larger than the element, you can create smooth, moving gradient effects.

Your First Tutorial: Making Beautiful Gradients In this tutorial, you will learn how to create three stunning types of CSS gradients. By the end, you'll be able to add depth and vibrancy to any web page. Goal Create a "Sunset Horizon" linear gradient, a "Vibrant Orb" radial gradient, and a "Rainbow Wheel" conic gradient. Step 1: Create a Linear Gradient (The Sunset) Linear gradients flow in a straight line. We will create a warm sunset effect. Create the HTML Container: Add a div with the class gradient-sunset to your HTML file. html
Add the CSS: In your CSS file, add the following code. It defines a width, height, and the linear gradient. css .gradient-sunset { width: 400px; height: 200px; background: linear-gradient(to right, #ff7e5f, #feb47b 25%, #fd1d1d 50%, #fdb321 75%, #ff7e5f); border-radius: 10px; box-shadow: 0 4px 8px rgba(0,0,0,0.1); } Live Preview: Step 2: Create a Radial Gradient (The Orb) Radial gradients start from a center point. Let's make a glowing orb. Create the HTML Container: Add a div with text inside. html
Radiate!
Add the CSS: css .gradient-orb { width: 300px; height: 300px; background: radial-gradient(ellipse at center, #56ab2f, #a8e6cf 40%, #88d8a3 70%, #f0f8ff); border-radius: 50%; /* Makes it a perfect circle */ display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center; color: white; font-size: 24px; font-weight: bold; } Live Preview: Radiate! Step 3: Create a Conic Gradient (The Rainbow) Conic gradients rotate around a center, perfect for color wheels. Create the HTML Container: html
Add the CSS: css .gradient-rainbow { width: 300px; height: 300px; background: conic-gradient(from 0deg, red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, violet, red); border-radius: 50%; } Live Preview: Next Steps Try combining these techniques! You can layer gradients (separating them with commas) or animate them using @keyframes to create moving backgrounds.

docs.text: Getting Started Ready to start painting with code? Follow these simple steps to set up the CSS Gradients application on your local machine. Prerequisites A text editor (like VS Code, Sublime Text, or Notepad). A modern web browser (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, or Edge). Setup Steps Locate the Project Files Navigate to the Gradients/ folder in the project directory. You should see files like linearGradient.html , radialGradient.html , and styles.css . Open an HTML File Double-click on linearGradient.html to open it in your web browser. You will see a live preview of a linear gradient. Open the Code Right-click the same file ( linearGradient.html ) and select "Open with" -> [Your Text Editor]. Do the same for styles.css . Edit and Refresh Change a color code in styles.css (e.g., change red to blue ), save the file, and refresh your browser. Watch the gradient change instantly! You are now ready to create your own designs.
docs.title: Getting Started

docs.text: Exploring Key Features The CSS Gradients application empowers you with three distinct tools to shape light and color. Linear Gradients What it is: A transition of colors along a straight line. Use it for: Backgrounds, buttons, and progress bars. Example: background: linear-gradient(to right, blue, green); Live Preview: This creates a flow from left (blue) to right (green). Radial Gradients What it is: A transition that radiates from a central point. Use it for: Spotlights, sun effects, or drawing focus to a specific element. Example: background: radial-gradient(circle, yellow, black); Live Preview: This creates a yellow center fading into a black edge. Conic Gradients What it is: A color transition rotated around a center point, like a clock face. Use it for: Pie charts, color wheels, and metallic reflections. Example: background: conic-gradient(red, blue, red); Live Preview: Performance & Accessibility Fast Loading: Gradients are generated by code, so they load instantly compared to large image files. Scalable: They look sharp on any screen size, from watches to large monitors. Accessible: You can easily tweak contrast to ensure text remains readable.
